text: Because I know there are a lot of folks out there who don't have backgrounds in traditional finance. Let's talk about what this all means. speaker: D
text: Yeah. So generally speaking, you have different regimes in markets. I'm going to take this back to a high level. And the regime for the last decade was one where when people go risk on, when investors go risk on and want to deploy capital in riskier assets. You saw two things happen together. You saw the ten year yield go up, which means that they're selling treasuries and you saw the dollar fall. And those are interrelated, right? Because the inverse of that is when there's fear globally, people go to the safest currency, the dollar, and they buy treasuries as a safe haven, and you see the ten year yield come down. So historically, the dollar falling and the ten year yield going up was a risk on. And by historically, I mean for the last decade, a risk on combination. Last year was a different regime. And what was different about last year was part of the reason why the ten year yield was going up was a recalibration around inflation expectations and around the view that the Fed was going to continue to fight inflation regardless of what was happening with the economy. So again, normally, if it looked like the economy was slowing, you get a bid on the ten year and the yield comes down. But this fear that the Fed was behind the curve on inflation and had to keep raising rates meant that even if there was fear around the economy, the ten year yield kept going up. So what we think has happened here, and the reason why we've gone to more of a neutral rather than macro headwind, is the fact that we think we're back in that regime from the last decade, where the fact that the ten year yield is going up is actually not a headwind for the equities market. And again, not talking about what we think is going to happen, but just what's happened over the last month, where you've had a big increase in the ten year yield, and it hasn't had a negative effect on the equities market.

speaker: B
text: And obviously, equity markets and digital asset markets, crypto markets, have been tightly correlated during this period. If you look at the ten year treasury yield chart going back some 40 years, you'll see that that's been dropping very dramatically in a secular way. You're talking about these cyclical shifts that we see relative to the correlation between investors pricing US treasury debt and us equities, particularly.

speaker: D
text: And by the way, so to your point, it's very noticeable if you look at both the Fed funds rate, so the very short end of the curve, or if you look further out, to your point, over the last, really 40 years, from 1980 to today, youve had this trend of lower highs and lower lows, and then you hit zero, and now were coming back off of zero. One of the reasons why is because the debt load has increased. So the question is, are we going to be able to sustain rates at a high level? How long will it take for rates at these levels to either crowd out other spending or have a negative effect on the economy as a result of how much debt is out in the economy and I, and lead to the Fed having to cut rates again. And the mental model that I use there is, it's likely to be very similar for crypto as Macau is for gaming. So kind of the offshore jurisdiction for mainland China for engaging with crypto. And then Singapore is a jurisdiction that is very interested in the most innovative parts of crypto. They're concerned about retail marketing, but they're very interested in having the most innovative parts of crypto come to Singapore as a jurisdiction, a friendly regulatory jurisdiction, to develop new protocols. And so there are actually quite a few places around the world that will welcome teams that feel like the regulatory uncertainty of the US is a little too much to bear at the moment.
